thread.title: Indispensable Odell Beckham returns to save Giants in nick of time
thread.title_full: Indispensable Odell Beckham returns to save Giants in nick of time | New York Post

author: Steve Serby
title: Indispensable Odell Beckham returns to save Giants in nick of time
text:
Odell Beckham Jr. caught the ball at the 15, put a spin move on Kenneth Acker, and boogied in the end zone.
And then came this announcement regarding Beckham in the press box: “His return is questionable with a hamstring injury.”
The mere mention of hamstring sends shudders through Big Blue Nation. A hamstrung Beckham means a hamstrung season, even when Victor Cruz returns, whenever that might be. Beckham felt a tug five plays or so before the touchdown.
And so it was 49ers 27, Giants 23 when Eli Manning tried to remember how to fashion a fourth-quarter comeback, only now without Beckham and a hamstrung Rueben Randle.
Manning started at his 18, 1:41 and three timeouts left. He scrambled for 11 yards. Hit Shane Vereen for 11. Timeout, 1:11 left. Hit Vereen for 16. Timeout, :050. Tony Jerod-Eddie pressured Manning into what was ruled on the field a Tramaine Brock interception.
Replay review reversed it.
Beckham came back. Beckham came back! Had he lobbied the medical team?
“Every second,” coach Tom Coughlin said.
Coughlin sounded as if he might have been lobbing on Beckham’s behalf, too.
“We’re trying to win a game,” Coughlin said.
Beckham felt as if he had let his team down.
“There’s no way in a moment like that that you can’t step up,” Beckham said.
The clock read 41 seconds.
Manning dumped off to Vereen for 24 yards, timeout with 30 seconds left.
“He’s great out of the backfield,” Manning said.
Manning looked for Beckham, of course he did.
Interference on Acker.
“The guy held him,” Manning said. “He was going to best him.”
Twenty six seconds left, ball at the 12.
“I’m going to throw you open if your guy’s back’s turned to me,” Manning told tight end Larry Donnell.
Manning, on his 54th pass attempt, found Donnell reaching over NaVorro Bowman in the back of the end zone with 21 seconds left — one tight end and one team dedicating the game to fallen tight end Daniel Fells (who could lose foot in MRSA battle).
Giants 30, 49ers 27.
First-place Giants.
Twenty-seven fourth-quarter comeback wins for Manning, the greatest quarterback in franchise history.
“He’s our guy,” Coughlin said.
Their guy was asked if this comeback was about as satisfying as any.
“A couple in the Super Bowl, obviously, but uh,” Manning said, and chuckled, and everyone laughed along.
Regular-season?
“This one was special,” Manning said, “just because we haven’t been as good as the two-minute drives as we once were.”
Eli Manning and Odell Beckham Jr. talk during the game. Photo: Joseph E. Amaturo Their guy is paid to carry the team on his shoulders in its hour of need.
“We had the opportunity, and that’s what they expect from me, what my teammates expect and coaches and fans, and myself,” Manning said.
Manning became the winningest quarterback (102) in franchise history and his 41 completions broke Phil Simms’ franchise record.
Their guy didn’t expect Beckham to return.
“If he wasn’t going to start that drive, he probably wouldn’t going to come back in,” Manning said.
Manning finished 41-54 for 441 yards, three touchdowns, one interception.
“It was fun,” Manning said. “We were going after it, we were pushing the ball down the field. … I thought it was a great offensive effort, and I thought we had great rhythm all game.”
It was 20-20 when Manning and the Giants first tried to remember how to finish the fourth quarter, only now without Beckham.
Manning hit rookie Geremy Davis for 16 yards, then Randle for 8 yards for his career-best 35th completion. Acker nearly intercepted him in the end zone, breaking Manning’s streak of 15 straight completions. Third-and-7 at the 11. Manning handed off to Vereen. Field goal.
It left Colin Kaepernick with 4:29 to cover 80 yards.
He needed just 1:44.
And so it was 49ers 27, Giants 23 when Manning remembered how to fashion a fourth-quarter comeback, without Beckham and a hamstrung Randle. With the rookie Davis and Dwayne Harris and Myles White and Will Tye from Stony Brook.
Manning and Beckham had started out like some East Coast version of Joe Montana and Jerry Rice, but Beckham had disappeared after the first two series (five receptions, 89 yards receiving), and Manning tossed a regrettable end-zone pick at the end of the first half.
With the 49ers playing Me And My Shadow with Beckham, with little semblance of a running game, with a defense further depleted by the early loss of Jon Beason (concussion), the game quickly rested on Manning’s right arm, and his head. His job to find a way to win.
His mission: find Beckham.
Manning found Beckham over the middle for 15 yards at the 49ers’ 34. It marked the ninth 100-yard game of Beckham’s career. Then Manning found Beckham, and it was Giants 20, 49ers 13.
Beckham vowed afterward that he was OK.
“It won’t be long at all,” he said. Asked about his tears during a post game interview, Beckham said: “It seems like we’re always counted out. It was just great to see this team and the fans just light the stadium up.”
Not to mention the quarterback you never count out.
